headline: Candy Cane Fudge
description: This holiday peppermint fudge is easy to make with baking chips, condensed milk, peppermint extract, and candy canes. Guaranteed to disappear quickly!

video.description: Holiday fudge that's perfect for gift-giving or parties.
video.name: candy cane fudge

name: Candy Cane Fudge
recipeIngredient: 1 dash red or green food coloring

recipeInstructions.text: Line an 8-inch square baking pan with aluminum foil; spray with nonstick spray and set aside.

Combine vanilla chips and sweetened condensed milk in a saucepan over medium heat. Stir frequently until chips are almost melted; remove from heat and continue to stir until smooth. Stir in candy canes, peppermint extract, and food coloring.
Spread evenly in the bottom of the prepared pan. Chill for 2 hours, then cut into squares.

review.reviewBody: I thought it was an awesome fudge , It turned out i had 10 people in the group that grew up with peppermint candy cane as a treat and they all said they have allergies to peppermint now . So i will only make it for the immediate family now . To me it was fantastic .
Easy and so yummy!! Loved it!
Super fast and easy. Sprinkled crushed candy canes and on top for Christmas and will add chopped cinnamon hearts for Valentine's. Freezes well.
I have made this a few times already and it's really good!
Very lovely and easy recipe. Absolutely loved it :)

This turned out to be a gooey mess! Worst thing I’ve ever made. Mixture did not set. Discarded the whole thing. I will never use this recipe again. Having done some research on fudge making after this failure, I discovered it didn’t set because it was not brought to a high enough temperature. This recipe makes no mention of bringing the mixture to a boil which is probably what’s needed for it to set. Also I think one single drop of food coloring is all that’s needed to make it look like the photo. My gooey mess turned out a pale green. To the person who submitted this recipe, please make instructions more precise. Do not assume we all know the fact that candy mixtures need to be brought to a high temperature in order to set.

This fudge is absolutely beautiful if you leave it white and allow the peppermint chips to color it. When food color is added, it was amazing how few people try those in comparison to the white. I think the fudge was delicious but remember it isn't that super-soft refrigerator fudge everyone has gotten used to- it has texture and body which makes it far easier to present without snagged or pulled edges, or smeared tops. The one thing I would leave out, unless everyone likes strong mint taste, is the peppermint extract. I had quite a few comments that the mint was a little "too much" and I would have to agree. The peppermints flavor it nicely all on their own! This is 5 star if you cut down or eliminate the extract. Nice job!
This is a huge hit at my work. People ask for this every year. I have played with this a little with choc chips and andy's mints. Not a fan of those so I stick with this original recipe.
I used white chocolate chips rather than vanilla. Fudge was delicious.

This was my first time making fudge ever! Everyone liked it too! Next time I make it I won't grind the candy canes into a fine powder ( I tried taking the easy way out and put them in my all powerful smoothie machine, they ened up way too ground up). After I made the recipe I found crushed candy canes for sell at Walmart. Also i used some Hershey's chocolate flavored peppermint candy canes too!
I did not like this recipe because it was really mushy and soggy...
I did not like this recipe because it was really mushy and soggy...
The family loved the fudge. Also, gave as part of neighbor treat gift boxes. Made as prescribed except added the food coloring and swirled at the end.
So delicious and easy to make as my first time making fudge!
This was a hit. Great idea for giveaways at Christmas. Very sweet.
Delish and soo easy
Made it as instructed. Everyone loved it. Perfect blend of ingredients without being overly sweet.
I didn't have vanilla chips, so I used white chocolate instead and doubled the peppermint extract to cut thru the extra sweetness. It was a big hit.

This was very easy to make! I did just use one cup of the crushed candy canes though. I didn't add the food coloring until after I poured it into the pan. A few drops on the top and then I swirled it in. This gave a nice look when it was finished and cut. I shared it with my neighbor and she just raved about it. I will make this again next year!
Super easy and delicious

I was surprised that I really liked this. The condensed milk flavor is very mild, being covered up by peppermint flavor, and was not detectable the next day. I made this at my 10-year old grandson’s request, and all three grandkids loved it. I’ll make this easy recipe again.
Very good! Even the non peppermint lovers liked this. I crushed the candy canes to a powder. Will def make again.
You MUST grease the foil! I did not and the whole thing stuck. We managed to salvage it and it was delish none the less!

Very good - but a couple points: Swirl the red food color through the fudge, or you end up with pink fudge. Also, reserve some of the candies to spread on top, instead of stirring them all into the fudge.
We did love it

This was my first time making fudge and certainly won’t be my last. Easy, simple and delicious - this recipe is loved by everyone. It looks delightful and festive, and tastes dreamy. What a holiday hit!
Way to sweet and really sticky! Will not make it again

Everyone loved these! I followed the directions exactly, except for the food coloring. Other reviewers suggested using a knife to swirl red stripes like a candy cane. Didn’t work! The mixture was too dense to pull that off. Fortunately I realized quickly and was able to contain the damage to a corner. I added red sparkles all over to make up for the lack of pink. Would make again!

To make the swirles and taste that I wa looking for, I let the chocolate completely melt and them added the extract and abit of cand cane. Once that had heated i poured into my pan and swirled about half a cup of candy cane and the food dye into the top of the fudge with the handle of a wooden spoon. Looks beautiful and has perfect taste and texture
Easy and so yummy!! Loved it!

I definitely would not call this a fudge as it is too soft (I like the description someone else gave of it being more fondant like). But despite it being quite soft and difficult to cut - even after being in the fridge for several hours - it tastes delicious and I do like it. If I made it again I would consider using small chocolate moulds or something similar so I did not need to try to cut it. The only change I made was to use 2 tsp of peppermint extract, which was perfect!
Made exactly as recipes states. I have been making this fudge for 5 yrs. I give it away as a gift which the recipients tell me they look forward to every Christmas.
These were a hit with party guests! I didn’t use any food coloring because I love the white color against the red candy cane. I used a 4 traditional sized candy canes.
A family favorite and Very easy to make!!! Good for any occasion even television night
I made this for a secret Santa and the people that I had ate it in two min!
I make this fudge every year at Christmas time and it just keeps getting better every time. I could eat that stuff for every meal its so delicious.
Followed the recipe. Turned out great was a bit with the family.
I made 2 types of fudge and this was the favourite. It set perfectly and tasted delicious.
Not a traditional fudge consistency but it works well for the holidays.

Super easy and delicious!! I'm new to making fudge and this recipe made it seem as though I'd been making it for years. We took it to a Christmas party and received compliments from everyone, including a call two days later.
I did not use any extract and simply ground some of the candy cane pieces into tiny bits (almost dust) to mix into the batter. I saved slightly larger pieces for the top.
Eh. Didnt make 64 cubes. It was really rich and was a better addition to cookie plates instead of obscure pieces of "peppermint bark"
It didn't set at all! So disappointed as I chose to make this instead of my normal fudge for Christmas.
Super easy and yummy.

I followed this recipe minus the food coloring and I used white chocolate chips because I couldn't find vanilla chips. This fudge has a lovely flavor but it didn't set as expected. I set it in the refrigerator for 6 hours and it still had a sticky texture- which is strange because I also made two similar ingredient recipes and they set just fine. I was able to cut it into squares but the tacky texture made it difficult to work with. Also, I lined my pan with non-stick aluminum foil which worked great.
Loved it, It helps to freeze the peppermint before you crush it.

Easy recipe to use. First time actually making fudge that was not like taffy. I used the mini candy canes (about 50 of them) and crushed them in a plastic bag. I put a drop of food coloring in the middle of the 8x8 pan and then in each of the 4 quadrants and swirled. Very yummy and not over powering for peppermint. I will make again.

First of all, I make A LOT of candy to give as gifts at Christmas and am always on the lookout for new and pretty candy recipes. Well, I made this but mine came out looking nothing like the picture. First of all, I think this would have been much better IF ithe chips and sweetened condensed milk were combined over a double boiler. Yes, mine melted just fine as the directions said but it thickens really quick because of the direct heat. I stirred my peppermint flavoring in off the heat (and the mixture really started thickening up), then the crushed peppermint, and finally the red food coloring. By time everything was combined, mine was more pink than white. Big disappointment! Not sure how to get it to look like red marbled swirls as shown in the picture. 
Flavor is okay - nothing special to me and I do like peppermint candy. I taste more of the sweetened condensed milk than anything. Don't think I'll waste either my time or money making this one again.

I made a quadruple batch of this recipe. I have a lot of people that I need to give handmade gifts to, and this was the perfect match recipe to do that! I did add more peppermint extract at the recommendation of other reviewers. I tasted it with the amount recommended in the recipe, and I could barely taste any peppermint at all. If you're like me and you like a good minty flavor, you'll want to add more. Also, at the recommendation of other reviewers are used one half vanilla chips and one half white chocolate. The result was a very creamy soft fudge. My husband is allergic to chocolate and this is his new favorite fudge.
My 10 year old and I made this for our neighborhood Christmas party. It was easy, fun and yummy! It's rich so you can cut in small pieces to serve many folks. We will be making this again soon!
They came out pretty good although they still stuck to the foil a bit.

Made this for my mom's Christmas party at work and she said it was a HUGE hit!! It was super easy and only tweaked it a bit. I used the soft, ball shaped peppermints and crushed them and put them in the mixture and on top before cooling them! They were soo good! I definitely will be making these from now on!!
I'm not a peppermint fan, but absolutely loved this fudge. It was a big hit at the family Christmas party!
So easy and delicious!!!
Delicious! Very rich. I left out the food coloring. Gave away some as gifts.
It was great!

Nice color contrast and flavor contrast to all the other sweets. Recommend: 1. not using food processor to crush candy cane because all the pretty striping was ground off the pieces. 2. Not mixing red food color into mix. White/red mix is prettier IMHO.

The recipe, as is, took almost two full boxes of candy canes. I started making this to use up old candy canes from last year but ended up rushing to the store to grab another box. Despite this, the fudge turned out really well. I would suggest leaving out the food coloring as the candy cane pieces make a great pink-marble effect. For an decorative element, just leave a few larger chunks of candy cane to sprinkle on top before the fudge cools. The fudge really cools fast through! Melting the chips on medium heat allows the fudge to cool very quickly, making it thick and requiring lots of muscle to stir. Overall, I will make again, but with a few adjustments.

Absolutely loved it! I didn't use food coloring and I also used 2 teaspoons of peppermint extract, it added a lot to the taste! I recommed busting your peppermints first, the chips don't take long to melt at all. Oh and I saved some to sprinkle on top before I cooled it! I think this will be my yearly Christmas candy??

It is a tasty fudge. But I made it last year and the 1st batch didn't set as "fudge" your recipe calls for too much condensed milk. It should only need one can which here is 8 ounz. Last year I did it your way and it was too wet and sticky and wouldn't set. Then I redid it and with less condensed milk and it was more like a fudge. This year I forgot about the the way I did it properly and followed your recipe again and once again 14 ounz of condensed milk is way too much. Basically a waste :(

This was a great and easy recipe! I only had one package of white chocolate chips so I used semi - sweet chocolate chips instead! It was a great substitute, and the fudge still had the candy cane taste! I loved this recipe and will make it again!
This is my go-to fudge for Christmas. I make it a few times during December because it disappears quickly.
mmm hmmm yum
Love, love this recipe. I have made it numerous time and everyone loves it.

Love this recipe. I think I made it 3 times over the holidays last year. Every time I make it I put a tad more peppermint flavoring in but that is just a personal taste. Everyone loves this and it is great addition to any cookie plate.

I would have to agree with a previous reviewer... do not use Ghirardelli vanilla chips (my grocery store doesn't carry any other brand of vanilla chips so I had no choice). It ruined my fudge! After it began to melt in the saucepan, all the oils started to separate and oil dripped everywhere while trying to transport it from saucepan to dish. The peppermint oil isn't nearly enough because it barely had a minty taste. It sets up quickly and I had just enough time to add the peppermint pieces before it hardened. After transporting it to a dish, I had to get paper towels to sop up all the oil on top. Then I put it in the fridge.. big mistake! It got so hard you could barely take a bite. Very few people ate it and I ended up throwing most of it away. I will stick to regular fudge from now on.

This is pretty and it tastes festive, but it's essentially melted vanilla chips with candy cane mixed in, so I don't see how it could ever be classified as great. I served this with a large selection of cookies and this didn't make the top of the favorite list. I imagine if it were served alone, folks would eat it and say it's pretty good, but I don't think the taste really wow's anyone. I suspect the attraction is how festive it looks.
Tasty and easy.
Really wasn't impressed with this recipe. I won't be making it again. It was edible....but that's about as far as I can compliment it.

Made this as written. It seemed to take a long time for the vanilla chips to melt, and you do have to keep stirring them or they will start to burn. I used a mini food processor to chop up the candy canes, which was much easier than using a meat tenderizer on them like I started doing. I used 12 candy canes, and it was plenty pepper-minty.

I didn't like this very much the day I made it, but the flavors seemed to come together more the next day. I used white chocolate chips, and while this turned out ok, I much prefer the Peppermint Brittle recipe on this site. Still, people liked it - didn't get rave reviews, but it made a nice addition to my cookies trays.
Yummy!
My daughter and i made this over the weekend.... OMG is it good.

Wasn't as good as I thought it would be. When I put it into the pan, the oil started seeping to the top. It leaves a pretty good aftertaste, I might try it again. It's texture wasn't quite like the chocolate fudge I make sometimes.

For my peppermint lover granddaughter!
sure hope she likes it.

This is the best peppermint fudge recipe I have tried. It is definitely rich, I cut mine into 1 inch squares. I opted to leave out the food coloring, it is beautiful with just the crushed candy canes on top.
Very good recipe! I used milk chocolate chips instead, and only put the crushed candy canes on the top instead of mixed in. Quite delicious and will certainly make it again!
The taste is fabulous, it looks beautiful and came out a pretty pink. It was incredibly popular and I made a few batches.

Thank you for this!!! I cannot eat chocolate so fudge (and holidays in general) are difficult for me to have desserts. This was my first ever attempt at fudge and it came out sinfully divine. I made it for Christmas dinner and everyone loved it. It has this wonderful texture, you just can't help yourself. I didn't crush candy canes. I got lucky and found white chocolate candies filled with candy canes at Costco, so I grabbed them up. Then at the last minute I found Andes white and peppermint bits at Target. I added all of the Costco candies and a handful of the Andes bits, everything melted down perfectly. Then I sprinkled the Andes bits on top, beautiful. Oh! I also didn't add any food coloring, since it isn't good for you (LOL! Who cares when making fudge, right! Silly.) but it was very pretty regardless, nice pink color. I suggest you cut it into small pieces just because it is so rich. Enjoy!
This tasted more like peppermint white chocolate. Everyone who ate it liked it.
It looked nothing like the picture and no one ate it.
This was fine, but not the consistency of fudge. It was too hard and dry. No one in my family really ate it. I did increase the peppermint extract to 1 tsp and it was still hard to taste the flavor.
Awesome...also used white chocolate chips as could not find vanilla...hardest part was unwrapping the candy canes...

very yummy! I tried to take others advice and swirl in the food coloring at the end but I worked too slow. Watch out, it hardens quickly. I used white chocolate chips since that's all I could find and it's VERY sweet, but looking at the ingredients I would expect that. I would make it again.
I liked it...it wasn't bad. I would have liked it more if I had had enough candy canes but unfortunately realized at the end I was about a half cup short. Was good anyway though.
Delicious...a hit at our Christmas party!!! I would not change one thing!!!
I made this for co-workers and they all loved it!! I also doubled the recipe for a large batch. Will make this for more gifts in the future!
This is SO easy to make and delicious!

I mad this as a Christmas gift for my work colleagues, and while it was too sweet for me, they loved it! My son has been sneaking pieces every time I turn my back.

I melted the chips and condensed milk in the microwave instead of in a saucepan...much easier! It is a very thick mixtue and does begin to thicken even more very quickly, so I also stuck it back in the microwave for a few seconds to loosen it up and get it into the pan. I'll be making it again!! 3 batches in and still getting requests...
it was easy and great!
Very easy to make - huge hit - different than the ordinary holiday treat.
Great recipe but only use 3/4 cup of crushed candy canes...1 1/2 is way to much

Easy and delightful recipe! I used 18 normal-sized candy canes - 12 crushed and mixed into the chocolate/condensed milk, and 6 crushed and sprinkled on top. Doubled the mint extract because I wanted it extra minty; a few drops of red food coloring and it's peppermint candy pink! So cute and festive! Only problem I had with the recipe was the instruction to melt over medium heat - I assumed the condensed milk would keep the chocolate from burning, but it didn't. The candy doesn't taste burnt at all, but there are little brown flecks in it. Please use a double boiler to melt the chocolate!

I don't think this qualifies as a "fudge" but it tastes great! I doubled the amount of peppermint extract, and it's been a huge holiday and party hit for a couple years now! I leave out the red food coloring, as it tends to come out light pink, and isn't esthetically pleasing. I leave mine in the fridge over night before cutting. It is quite sweet/rich, so I usually cut it into small pieces.
Make it during Christmas each year. Love it.
Love for Christmas!
it was ok too much peppermint

I tried this at Christmastime to add to a variety of goodies I made for a group at work. It went over very well and, as all fudge is very sweet, the peppermint took away some of the rich sweet flavor mixing its own wonderful minty flavor with it.

I wish I could give this a 10 star rating for presentation. It was beautiful and so festive. Everyone was excited and intrigued. I only used red food coloring, and it was really, super pretty. Everyone who tasted it also really liked the flavor. The change I would make would be to make sure the candy canes are totally crushed- biting into a piece of candy cane sort of spoils the experience. I crushed mine pretty good, but next time will crush completely. Great recipe.

This was pretty good but not the best fudge I've had. I definitely would recommend skipping the red food coloring. I just gently swirled it in but it gave the fudge an overall odd-color which I think was off-putting.
